messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 45 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Tight Quantum Time-Space Tradeoffs for Function Inversion

Paper Abstract: Abstract In function inversion, we are given a function f:[N]↦[N]:𝑓maps-todelimited-[]𝑁delimited-[]𝑁f:[N]\mapsto[N], and want to prepare some advice of size S𝑆S, such that we can efficiently invert any image in time T𝑇T. This is a well studied problem with profound connections to cryptography, data structures, communication complexity, and circuit lower bounds. Investigation of this problem in the quantum setting was initiated by Nayebi, Aaronson, Belovs, and Trevisan (2015), who proved a lower bound of S​T2=Ω~​(N)𝑆superscript𝑇2~Ω𝑁ST^{2}=\tilde{\Omega}(N) for random permutations against classical advice, leaving open an intriguing possibility that Grover’s search can be sped up to time O~​(N/S)~𝑂𝑁𝑆\tilde{O}(\sqrt{N/S}). Recent works by Hhan, Xagawa, and Yamakawa (2019), and Chung, Liao, and Qian (2019) extended the argument for random functions and quantum advice, but the lower bound remains S​T2=Ω~​(N)𝑆superscript𝑇2~Ω𝑁ST^{2}=\tilde{\Omega}(N). In this work, we prove that even with quantum advice, S​T+T2=Ω~​(N)𝑆𝑇superscript𝑇2~Ω𝑁ST+T^{2}=\tilde{\Omega}(N) is required for an algorithm to invert random functions. This demonstrates that Grover’s search is optimal for S=O~​(N)𝑆~𝑂𝑁S=\tilde{O}(\sqrt{N}), ruling out any substantial speed-up for Grover’s search even with quantum advice. Further improvements to our bounds would imply new classical circuit lower bounds, as shown by Corrigan-Gibbs and Kogan (2019). To prove this result, we develop a general framework for establishing quantum time-space lower bounds. We further demonstrate the power of our framework by proving the following results. • Yao’s box problem: We prove a tight quantum time-space lower bound for classical advice. For quantum advice, we prove a first time-space lower bound using shadow tomography. These results resolve two open problems posted by Nayebi et al (2015). • Salted cryptography: We show that “salting generically provably defeats preprocessing,” a result shown by Coretti, Dodis, Guo, and Steinberger (2018), also holds in the quantum setting. In particular, we prove quantum time-space lower bounds for a wide class of salted cryptographic primitives in the quantum random oracle model. This yields the first quantum time-space lower bound for salted collision-finding, which in turn implies that 𝖯𝖶𝖯𝖯𝒪⊈𝖥𝖡𝖰𝖯𝒪/𝗊𝗉𝗈𝗅𝗒not-subset-of-or-equalssuperscript𝖯𝖶𝖯𝖯𝒪superscript𝖥𝖡𝖰𝖯𝒪𝗊𝗉𝗈𝗅𝗒\mathsf{PWPP}^{\mathcal{O}}\not\subseteq\mathsf{FBQP}^{\mathcal{O}}\mathsf{/qpoly} relative to a random oracle 𝒪𝒪\mathcal{O}.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 45 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 45"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Limitations of Quantum Advice and One-Way Communication",
        "Shadow tomography of quantum states",
        "Quantum security proofs using semi-classical oracles",
        "Gentle measurement of quantum states and differential privacy",
        "XChaCha: eXtended-nonce ChaCha and AEAD_XChaCha20_Poly1305 Work in Progress",
        "Quantum lower bounds for the collision and the element distinctness problems",
        "Strengths and weaknesses of quantum computing",
        "Random Oracles in a Quantum World",
        "A General Sequential Time-Space Tradeoff for Finding Unique Elements",
        "Random Oracles are Practical: A Paradigm for Designing Efficient Protocols",
        "Quantum Complexity Theory",
        "Secure Signatures and Chosen Ciphertext Security in a Quantum Computing World",
        "Non-Uniform Bounds in the Random-Permutation, Ideal-Cipher, and Generic-Group Models",
        "Random Oracles and Non-uniformity",
        "The function-inversion problem: Barriers and opportunities",
        "Lower Bounds for Function Inversion with Quantum Advice",
        "Security of the fiat-shamir transformation in the quantum random-oracle model",
        "Fixing Cracks in the Concrete: Random Oracles with Auxiliary Input, Revisited",
        "Time Space Tradeoffs for Attacks against One-Way Functions and PRGs",
        "Rigorous Time/Space Trade-offs for Inverting Functions",
        "3SUM with Preprocessing: Algorithms, Lower Bounds and Cryptographic Applications",
        "On the existence of pseudorandom generators",
        "A fast quantum mechanical algorithm for database search",
        "A cryptanalytic time-memory trade-off",
        "Quantum Time-Space Tradeoffs by Recording Queries",
        "Quantum Random Oracle Model with Auxiliary Input",
        "Relativized separations of worst-case and average-case complexities for NP",
        "Quantum time-space tradeoffs for sorting",
        "A Concrete Treatment of Fiat-Shamir Signatures in the Quantum Random-Oracle Model",
        "The Strong 3SUM-INDEXING Conjecture is False",
        "Quantum and classical strong direct product theorems and optimal time-space tradeoffs",
        "One-way functions and pseudorandom generators",
        "Cryptographic Algorithms for the TCP Authentication Option (TCP-AO)",
        "On finding quantum multi-collisions",
        "Revisiting Post-Quantum Fiat-Shamir.",
        "Prediction from Partial Information and Hindsight, with Application to Circuit Lower Bounds",
        "Quantum lower bound for inverting a permutation with advice",
        "Prediction from partial information and hindsight, an alternative proof",
        "Post-Quantum Security of the Fujisaki-Okamoto and OAEP Transforms",
        "Random Oracles and Auxiliary Input",
        "Non-Interactive Zero-Knowledge Proofs in the Quantum Random Oracle Model",
        "Post-quantum Security of Fiat-Shamir",
        "Coherent functions and program checkers",
        "Secure Identity-Based Encryption in the Quantum Random Oracle Model",
        "How to record quantum queries, and applications to quantum indifferentiability"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 45 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Tight Quantum Time-Space Tradeoffs for Function Inversion, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
